importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Date of the run-off election, marking a pivotal political shift in Bolivia after decades of socialist rule.
The inauguration date of the newly elected president following the run-off vote, indicating the start of a new political era.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The voting period for the presidential run-off, with polling stations open from 8am to 4pm local time, and results expected five hours later.

keyTakeAways: Bolivia is set to hold a presidential run-off election, ending nearly two decades of socialist governance under the Movement Towards Socialism (MAS) party.
The election pits conservative former interim President Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga (65) against centrist economist and Senator Rodrigo Paz (58), son of former left-wing President Jaime Zamora.
Both candidates promise to reform Bolivia’s crisis-hit economy, reduce inflation, and restore relations with the United States after years of hostility under Evo Morales and Luis Arce.
Bolivia faces a severe economic crisis: inflation over 20%, fuel and dollar shortages, and long queues at petrol stations, contributing to widespread public discontent.
The MAS party failed to field a candidate for the run-off, signaling the collapse of its political dominance and a potential shift toward market-friendly policies.
Public sentiment reflects desperation: citizens like Felicidad Flores and Javier Quispe express economic hardship and low hope for improvement.
The election marks a political turning point, with analysts indicating a move away from left-wing policies toward market liberalism and closer alignment with the United States.
Both candidates propose reducing the universal fuel subsidy to only cover public transport, aiming to improve fiscal sustainability.
The US government, including Secretary of State Marco Rubio, sees the election as a transformative opportunity to rebuild bilateral relations with Bolivia.

Despite the electoral shift, governing may be difficult due to lack of congressional support and continued influence of former President Evo Morales, who remains politically active despite facing a human trafficking arrest warrant.
Nearly eight million Bolivians are eligible to vote, and voting is mandatory, indicating high public engagement and potential for social unrest if reforms fail to address the vulnerable populations.

namedEntities.name: Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is one of the two main candidates in the presidential run-off, representing a conservative, pro-market stance and promising radical economic reforms.

namedEntities.name: Rodrigo Paz
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the other main candidate in the run-off, advocating a moderate, inclusive capitalist approach with support for social programs.

namedEntities.name: Movement Towards Socialism (MAS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Dominant political party in Bolivia since 2006
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The party failed to advance a candidate to the run-off, marking the end of its 20-year political dominance and signaling a shift in political power.

namedEntities.name: Evo Morales
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former President of Bolivia, leader of MAS
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His long-standing socialist leadership ended with the MAS's failure to win a candidate, and his influence remains in the political landscape despite being barred from running.

namedEntities.name: Luis Arce
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Succeeded Morales and contributed to the current economic crisis; his successor status underscores the transition in political leadership.

namedEntities.name: Marco Rubio
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He has publicly endorsed the election as a transformative opportunity for U.S.-Bolivia relations, signaling a shift toward improved bilateral ties.

namedEntities.name: Felicidad Flores
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She represents a citizen voice expressing public economic hardship and hope for change.

namedEntities.name: Javier Quispe
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He symbolizes widespread public discontent due to fuel shortages and economic decline.

namedEntities.name: Glaeldys Gonzalez Calanche
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Political analyst for International Crisis Group
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She identifies the election as a political turning point, highlighting the country’s shift toward new governance models.

namedEntities.name: Daniela Osorio
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Analyst from German Institute for Global and Area Studies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She warns of potential social unrest if reforms fail to assist vulnerable populations.

namedEntities.name: Bolivia
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The country is facing its worst economic crisis in decades, with inflation, fuel shortages, and political realignment shaping national dynamics.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Country with which Bolivia has strained relations
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The election marks a potential return to improved U.S.-Bolivia relations after decades of anti-U.S. policies under leftist governments.

namedEntities.name: Fuel subsidy
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Policy proposal to limit universal fuel subsidy
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Both candidates support curtailing the subsidy to public transport to ease fiscal strain, signaling economic reform.

namedEntities.name: November 8
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Inauguration date of the new president
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The official start date of the new government following the run-off election.

namedEntities.name: August 2025
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The MAS party’s collapse in the first round of voting occurred in August, leading to the run-off election.

namedEntities.name: 1990s
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Era of market-friendly economic policies in Bolivia
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The election is seen as a return to market policies of the 1990s, though with differences in approach between candidates.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Bolivia is holding a presidential run-off election on October 19, 2025, marking the end of nearly two decades of socialist rule under the Movement Towards Socialism (MAS) party. The vote pits conservative former interim President Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga against centrist economist Rodrigo Paz, both of whom promise to reform the country’s crisis-hit economy, reduce inflation, and restore relations with the United States. The nation, facing a severe economic downturn with inflation above 20%, fuel shortages, and long queues, sees this election as a turning point toward market-oriented policies. While both candidates propose cutting the universal fuel subsidy and opening the economy to foreign investment, the MAS party's failure to field a candidate in the first round signals a decisive political shift. Public sentiment reflects deep economic hardship, with citizens expressing low hope for improvement. Analysts warn that without meaningful reforms, especially for vulnerable populations, social unrest could follow. Despite the political change, challenges remain, including the continued influence of former President Evo Morales and the lack of congressional support for either candidate. The election is seen as a transformative moment in Bolivia’s political and economic trajectory, with potential long-term implications for U.S.-Bolivia relations.
title: Crisis-hit Bolivia to vote in run-off election, ending decades of socialism
